details.name: FBN1
details.description: Fibrillin 1 gene associated with colorectal cancer (CRC)
details.findings: Shows differential methylation in CRC cases compared to controls
details.notes: Identified through DNA methylation analysis using EPIC arrays

details.name: RBP4
details.description: Retinol-binding protein 4 gene associated with CRC
details.findings: Exhibits differential methylation patterns in CRC cases
details.notes: Part of a panel of methylation markers for CRC detection

details.name: C7orf10
details.description: Chromosome 7 open reading frame 10 gene linked to CRC
details.findings: Demonstrates significant methylation changes in CRC
details.notes: Potential marker for early detection of CRC

details.name: TFPI2
details.description: Tissue factor pathway inhibitor 2 gene associated with CRC
details.findings: Shows altered methylation in colorectal cancer tissues
details.notes: Correlates with clinical outcomes in CRC patients

details.name: EPO
details.description: Erythropoietin gene linked to CRC progression
details.findings: Exhibits hypermethylation in CRC cases
details.notes: Potential therapeutic target for CRC treatment

details.name: SLC6A20
details.description: Solute carrier family 6 member A20 gene associated with CRC
details.findings: Displays differential methylation in CRC cases compared to controls
details.notes: May play a role in CRC pathogenesis

details.name: IRF1
details.description: Interferon regulatory factor 1 gene linked to CRC
details.findings: Shows significant methylation changes in CRC cases
details.notes: Involved in immune response and tumor suppression

details.name: Immunoglobulin G (IgG)
details.description: A type of antibody with specific glycosylation patterns.
details.findings: Increased levels in certain inflammatory conditions.
details.notes: Commonly studied for its role in immune responses and inflammation.

details.name: Immunoglobulin A (IgA)
details.description: Another class of antibody with distinct glycosylation.
details.findings: Varies in abundance and response compared to IgG.
details.notes: Important in mucosal immunity.

details.name: Immunoglobulin M (IgM)
details.description: First antibody produced in response to an infection.
details.findings: Associated with a specific glycoform linked to certain diseases.
details.notes: Largest antibody, often indicative of recent infection.

details.name: Haptoglobin (Hp)
details.description: Binds free hemoglobin to prevent oxidative damage.
details.findings: Exists in two isoforms, Hp1 and Hp2, which are associated with different disease states.
details.notes: Used as a marker for hemolysis and inflammation.

details.name: Transferrin (Tf)
details.description: Involved in iron transport and homeostasis.
details.findings: Shows specific glycan structures that are altered in chronic inflammation.
details.notes: Important for understanding iron metabolism disorders.

details.name: Ceruloplasmin (Cp)
details.description: Involved in iron metabolism and antioxidant defense.
details.findings: Specific glycosylation patterns are associated with inflammatory conditions.
details.notes: Elevated levels are seen in acute-phase responses.

details.name: Alpha-2 macroglobulin (A2M)
details.description: A large plasma protein involved in immune regulation.
details.findings: Identified as a potential biomarker due to its glycosylation changes in inflammation.
details.notes: Plays a role in chronic inflammatory diseases.

details.name: Fetuin-A
details.description: Inhibits calcification and regulates insulin activity.
details.findings: Levels are altered in certain inflammatory and metabolic conditions.
details.notes: Associated with cardiovascular diseases.

details.name: Albumin
details.description: Most abundant plasma protein, not a glycoprotein.
details.findings: Levels decrease in chronic inflammatory states due to capillary leakage.
details.notes: Common marker for nutritional status and liver function.

details.name: C-reactive protein (CRP)
details.description: Produced in response to inflammation.
details.findings: Levels increase significantly during bacterial infections and inflammatory conditions.
details.notes: Commonly used as a clinical marker for infection and inflammation.

details.name: Serum Amyloid A (SAA)
details.description: Increases rapidly in response to inflammation.
details.findings: Levels are elevated in chronic inflammatory conditions.
details.notes: Associated with amyloidosis and various infections.

details.name: Amyloid A
details.description: Associated with chronic inflammatory conditions and certain cancers.
details.findings: Linked to disease states through specific glycosylation patterns.
details.notes: Implicated in the pathogenesis of amyloidosis.

details.name: Lipoproteins (e.g., LDL, HDL)
details.description: Responsible for cholesterol and lipid transport.
details.findings: Show altered glycosylation patterns in metabolic disorders.
details.notes: Associated with cardiovascular diseases.

details.name: miR-126
details.description: A microRNA expressed in colorectal cancer exosomes (CEx) with potential as a diagnostic and prognostic biomarker.
details.findings: Reported as a potential biomarker for early CRC diagnosis and prognosis with robust predictive results.
details.notes: Part of a proposed CEx-miRNAs panel for minimally invasive CRC detection.

details.name: miR-1290
details.description: A microRNA associated with colorectal cancer exosomes and tumor progression.
details.findings: Identified as a potential biomarker for early CRC diagnosis and prognosis with strong predictive data.
details.notes: Included in the proposed panel of CEx-miRNAs for early CRC detection.

details.name: miR-23a
details.description: A microRNA linked to colorectal cancer progression and metastasis.
details.findings: Associated with tumor progression and angiogenesis in CRC.
details.notes: Part of the proposed panel for CEx-miRNAs-based early CRC detection.

details.name: miR-940
details.description: A microRNA found in colorectal cancer exosomes with diagnostic potential.
details.findings: Associated with CRC pathogenesis and proposed as a non-invasive biomarker.
details.notes: Included in the panel of CEx-miRNAs for early CRC detection.

details.name: MSI-H
details.description: A condition where there is a failure of the DNA mismatch repair system, leading to genomic instability.
details.findings: MSI-H status is predictive of response to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) and confers improved clinical outcomes with reduced toxicities.
details.notes: Identified as a key biomarker for immunotherapy in colorectal cancer.

knowledge.predicate: confers improved clinical outcomes with reduced toxicities

details.name: BRAF V600E mutation
details.description: A specific mutation in the BRAF gene, known to be oncogenic.
details.findings: BRAF V600E mutation is a negative prognostic marker but predicts response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition, doubling survival over standard treatments.
details.notes: Commonly found in colorectal cancers with poor prognosis if untreated appropriately.

knowledge.predicate: predicts response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition

details.name: RAS mutation
details.description: Mutations in the RAS gene family are associated with resistance to certain therapies.
details.findings: RAS mutations are predictive of resistance to anti-EGFR therapies.
details.notes: Commonly used as a marker to guide treatment decisions in colorectal cancer.

details.name: HLA-A*03 allele
details.description: A specific allele of the HLA-A gene, which plays a role in immune recognition.
details.findings: HLA-A*03 allele may predict clinical benefit with nivolumab and ipilimumab combination therapy.
details.notes: Emerging as a potential predictive marker for immunotherapy responses.

details.name: HER2 amplification
details.description: An increase in the number of HER2 gene copies, often associated with cancer progression.
details.findings: HER2 amplification is a potential target for anti-HER2 therapies.
details.notes: Less common but relevant in certain colorectal cancer cases.

details.name: HLA-B*15 and HLA-B*35 alleles
details.description: Specific alleles of the HLA-B gene associated with immune responses.
details.findings: HLA-B*15 and HLA-B*35 alleles are associated with improved overall survival in patients treated with nivolumab and ipilimumab combination therapy.
details.notes: Emerging biomarkers for immunotherapy response prediction.

details.name: KRAS mutation
details.description: A mutation in the KRAS gene, commonly implicated in cancer.
details.findings: KRAS mutations are associated with susceptibility to ferroptosis and may serve as a predictive marker for therapies targeting this pathway.
details.notes: Frequently mutated in colorectal cancers; potential role in novel therapeutic approaches.

details.name: MMR/MSI
details.description: A condition where there is a failure of the DNA mismatch repair system, leading to genomic instability.
details.findings: MMR/MSI status is predictive of response to immunotherapy and other targeted therapies in colorectal cancer.
details.notes: Closely related to MSI-H status; often used interchangeably in clinical contexts.

details.name: Ki-67
details.description: A nuclear protein that is expressed in all active phases of the cell cycle (G1, S, G2, and mitosis), but not in resting cells (G0). It is commonly used as a marker for cell proliferation.
details.findings: Overexpression of Ki-67 has been associated with worse clinical outcomes in various cancers, including breast cancer.
details.notes: Ki-67 expression levels are often assessed via immunohistochemistry in tumor samples to determine the growth fraction of cells.

knowledge.predicate: overexpression is associated with worse clinical outcomes

details.name: HER2
details.description: Human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) is a gene that can play a role in the development of breast cancer. When overexpressed, it is associated with aggressive tumor behavior.
details.findings: Amplification or overexpression of HER2 is found in approximately 20% of early-stage breast cancers and is associated with increased tumor aggressiveness and reduced survival rates if untreated.
details.notes: HER2 status is determined through immunohistochemistry (IHC) or fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). HER2-positive cancers are eligible for targeted therapies such as trastuzumab.

knowledge.predicate: overexpression is associated with aggressive tumor behavior

details.name: p53
details.description: The p53 gene produces a protein that plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle, preventing cells with damaged DNA from dividing. Mutations in p53 can lead to uncontrolled cell growth and cancer.
details.findings: Mutations in the p53 gene are found in approximately 50% of human cancers, including colorectal, breast, and lung cancers. These mutations often correlate with poor prognosis and increased metastatic potential.
details.notes: p53 mutations can lead to loss of normal tumor suppressor function, resulting in unchecked cell proliferation.

knowledge.predicate: mutations are associated with poor prognosis

details.name: ER (Estrogen Receptor)
details.description: The estrogen receptor (ER) is a protein that binds to the hormone estrogen. In breast cancer, ER positivity indicates that cancer cells may respond to endocrine therapies.
details.findings: Approximately 70-80% of breast cancers are ER-positive, meaning they express high levels of the ER protein. ER-positive tumors tend to grow slower and are more likely to respond to hormone therapy.
details.notes: ER status is determined through immunohistochemistry (IHC). Positive ER status is associated with improved survival rates when treated with endocrine therapies such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors.

knowledge.predicate: positivity indicates potential response to endocrine therapies

details.name: PR (Progesterone Receptor)
details.description: The progesterone receptor (PR) is a protein that binds to the hormone progesterone. In breast cancer, PR positivity often indicates a favorable prognosis and responsiveness to hormone therapies.
details.findings: PR-positive breast cancers are more likely to respond to endocrine therapies. The presence of PR often correlates with ER positivity, as both receptors are regulated by estrogen.
details.notes: PR status is also determined through immunohistochemistry (IHC). Positive PR status is generally associated with better clinical outcomes in breast cancer patients.

details.name: guanylate cyclase-C (GUCY2C)
details.description: A protein expressed in colorectal cancer cells but not in normal tissues.
details.findings: Expression of GUCY2C is associated with metastatic colorectal cancer and serves as a target for chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy. High expression levels may correlate with better treatment outcomes.
details.notes: GUCY2C immunohistochemistry was used to confirm its expression in tumor tissues.

details.name: GUCY2C immunohistochemistry
details.description: A method to detect the expression of GUCY2C protein in tissues.
details.findings: Used to confirm GUCY2C expression in tumor tissues, aiding in patient selection for targeted therapies.
details.notes: This assay helps identify patients who may benefit from GUCY2C-targeted treatments.

details.name: hCRISPRs
details.description: Human CRISPR sequences (hCRISPRs) are endogenous CRISPR-Cas systems found in the human genome.
details.findings: hCRISPRs can be used as biosensors for SARS-CoV-2 detection. They are more stable and abundant compared to exogenous CRISPR systems, making them suitable for diagnostic applications.
details.notes: hCRISPRs were tested using SHERLOCK and DETECTR technologies.

details.name: CRISPR-Cas systems
details.description: CRISPR-Cas systems are being explored for their potential as biosensors in diagnostics.
details.findings: Endogenous CRISPR-Cas systems like hCRISPRs show promise for detecting pathogens such as SARS-CoV-2 due to their stability and abundance.
details.notes: hCRISPRs are a subset of CRISPR-Cas systems found in the human genome.

knowledge.predicate: due to their stability and abundance

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A compound with an abnormal fruity odor, potentially used as a biomarker for cancer.
details.findings: Acetone concentration in breath changes during activities such as exercising or fasting, limiting its reliability as a standalone biomarker. It is considered an adequate cancer biomarker but not appropriate due to variability.
details.notes: Acetone levels are influenced by physical activities and metabolic states.

details.name: 4-Heptanone
details.description: A compound with unclear origins, limiting its use as a biomarker.
details.findings: The origin of 4-heptanone is unclear, making it unsuitable as a reliable biomarker for cancer.
details.notes: Its unclear origins limit its utility in cancer diagnostics.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A secondary product of lipid peroxidation, often associated with metabolic conditions involving high oxidation rates of fatty acids.
details.findings: Elevated levels in CRC patients' breath samples, identified via GC-MS analysis.
details.notes: Commonly associated with ketosis but also linked to oxidative stress in cancer contexts.

details.name: Alkenes
details.description: Unsaturated hydrocarbons with at least one double bond, often produced as byproducts of oxidative stress.
details.findings: Detected in breath samples of CRC patients; linked to oxidative stress mechanisms.
details.notes: Common biomarkers for oxidative stress-related conditions.

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: Primarily derived from food, alcohol beverages, or metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes.
details.findings: Present in breath samples, potentially indicating metabolic activity related to CRC.
details.notes: Can originate from dietary sources or metabolic processes.

details.name: Ketones
details.type: Organic compounds with a carbonyl group
details.description: Include acetone, which is associated with lipid peroxidation and oxidative stress.
details.findings: Elevated levels of ketones like acetone found in CRC patients' breath samples.
details.notes: Ketones are often markers of metabolic states such as ketosis.

details.name: Esters
details.type: Organic compounds with a carbonyl group
details.description: Commonly found in natural sources like fats, oils, and waxes; also present in breath samples.
details.findings: Detected in CRC patients' breath samples via GC-MS analysis.

details.name: Hydrocarbons

details.description: Produced as byproducts of oxidative stress, with alkenes being a specific subset.
details.findings: Altered levels in CRC patients' breath samples linked to oxidative stress mechanisms.
details.notes: Hydrocarbons like alkanes and alkenes are markers of oxidative processes.

details.name: Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS)
details.description: Key players in oxidative stress, leading to lipid peroxidation and hydrocarbon emissions.
details.findings: Elevated ROS levels contribute to CRC pathogenesis and biomarker production.

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: The T-antigen is an immature glycan signature found in stools, associated with abnormal glycosylation patterns.
details.findings: Stools from more aggressive lesions may exhibit abnormal immature glycan signatures not seen in healthy tissues. The T-antigen (core 1 glycans) is identified as a potential biomarker for non-invasive CRC screening.
details.notes: The T-antigen is specifically mentioned as part of core 1 glycans, which are associated with these abnormal signatures.

details.name: stool glycoproteome
details.description: The stool glycoproteome refers to the characterization of proteins and their glycan modifications found in stools.
details.findings: This work provides a characterization of the stool glycoproteome, identifying several molecular targets shared by more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer.
details.notes: The study emphasizes the potential of these biomarkers for future pre-clinical assessment.

[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are topic of the article and for each such biomarker extract name, description, type, findings explicitly mentioned in the article, list of knowledge that consist of 'predicate' about the finding from findings and 'object' which biomarker is subject and related via 'predicate'.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"findings about biomarker in article","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker", "knowledge":[{'predicate':'some predicate from findings of biomarker','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker' }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"findings about biomarker2 in article","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2", "knowledge":[{'predicate':'some predicate from findings of  biomarker2','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2' }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
